column1: Will China's Three Gorges Dam fail before 1 October 2020?
column6: ['Technology', 'Environment']
We are in the final hours. This will not likely happen.
Same as NK question. Your comments say 1%.
Seems very solid even with earthquakes and rising of dam levels
No
Not unless it gets struck by a meteor.
The worst of the floodwater has subsided for now, with no failure. Reports on the ground are less alarming, and there is very little time left now before the deadline.
Water level has gone up again, but will not reach dangerous levels before October 1st even if it continues to rise at the current rate. Still keeping a small percentage open for the unexpected.
decr
chance decreases with less time until resolution.

From 2003 to November 2008, 5503 earthquakes - roughly 1100 earthquakes per year (365 days). 1100/365 Roughly 3 per day 8 days left - 24% 2 days will be 6% I guess I'm a little unsure whether to compound the likelihood if an earthquake doesn't occur or each day resets like a coin toss.
Cannot predict mother nature . . .
Days for an earthquake to occur are reducing. Minimal rain
I think the probability has to be >0 (even if only slightly).
hold
Changing to crowd.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yWxJYAWchJs

Latest data show water level decreasing (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020_Three_Gorges_Dam_water_level.svg), but (a) thèse data are a week old and (b) dam collapse does not always happen at maximum capacity, but high volumes of water may weaken the structure that may fail at a later date.
No news is good news. No change for now, because of passage of time.
As the rainfall has subsided it is quite unlikely that the dam would give up now.
Hold

Dam was completed in 2006 and is likely proper maintenance is carried out on this dam due to the reliance of locals for high power output. It is also a safety concern in relation to floods The dam flooded various areas and has therefore increased risk of landslides locally There is minimal rainfall during September so a reduced likelihood of landslides The lifespan is somewhere between 50-100 years, especially with maintenance The dam sits on a seismic fault and the land in the area is experiencing erosion Long-term studies on the Yangtze Three Gorges area found that the crust in or around the dam site is stable, but a tectonic background exists that could induce seismic activity. Earthquakes: o 2008 – 4.1 magnitude; o 2013 – 5.1 magnitude From June 2003 to November 2008, 5503 earthquakes (M ≥ 0) were recorded by the Three Gorges seismic network. This total includes 4362 earthquakes of 0. 0 < M < 0. 9, 1030 earthquakes of 1.0 ≤ M < 2. 0, 106 earthquakes of 2. 0 ≤ M < 3. 0, and 4 earthquakes of 3.0 ≤ M < 4.0. Difficult to determine the magnitude of the next earthquake and when that will take place but there is only 12 days for it to take place and cause the dam to fail.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.
Decreasing with time and weather. Interesting correlation.
Something that seems strange is going on at the dam; they don't seem to be able to maintain a steady outflow, and the water level is rising again.
Reiterating

There are 2 ways I think this might happen: - Tropical Hurricane -> about a 1 in 1000 every year, and since hurricane season in china is almost over even lower - All-out conflict with Taiwan, India -> probability approaching 0 probably something like 0.01%
maintaining. non-zero chance, but below .2% probability, so rounding down.
Given the time-bound nature of the question and the fact that the worst of the monsoons in China have already passed, I don't think the dams are likely to fail by the end of this month.

Although I think the failure of any dam is a non-zero probability and the issues that with Three Gorges Dam are of greater concern than a dam with an established track record of success. In any given year I'd rate the probability of a failure occurring is in the low single digits (expressed in%). If I were an engineer on Three Gorges Dam or a leader in China I would be both looking to improve the dam and ensure that there are solid contingency plans for the surrounding area. However, given the short term nature of the question and that the hight of monsoon season is passed in China I'm rating the possible of a failure as 0%. @pstamp That was an interesting simulation. Thank you for sharing.
bent but not broken, in the time remaining seems increasingly unlikely.
Unless it gets hit by a meteor or Godzilla, this thing is not going anywhere.
No news is good news. Here´s a nice simulation, what would happen, if it did fail: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C-lAQiygOyU
Very little time left; the crowd is at 1%.
Decreasing
The worst case scenario seems to be behind us: - outflow is back to average level for flooding season - water level continues to trend down
Previously 1%; down to zero. The structure has been slightly damaged but not in imminent risk of failure.
decrease after pass of weather system
Move to 0% on the 15th.
3gd.mooo.com Downward trend suggests relaxation with brunt of rain over.
Not zero, but unlikely and less than 1%
Decreasing chances as we get closer to October...it is still standing.
Reasons
20 Notable Dam Failures in the World per Year = 200 / (2009 - 2000 + 1) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dam_failure

Updating due to one month to deadline.

“This past week, officials feared that the Three Gorges Dam on the mighty Yangtze was peaking and could overflow. Elsewhere, authorities have blown up barriers that were causing more damage than help.” https://english.aawsat.com/home/article/2475821/anjani-trivedi/big-china-disaster-you’re-missing -End of period- Remaining time base prediction correction past evident crisis to structure
I think that season which causes the most danger of flooding is passing. The dam managers seem to have calibrated and perfected their efforts. I am reverting to "normal" base-rate.
http://3gd.mooo.com/

Water level is still high at the dam, and drops slowly. Probably floodgates have been closed very soon after the inflow decreased in order to bring relief to downstream inhabitants, e.g. in Yichang. It's risky, the water management admin obviously bets the monsoon season 2020 will be over.

Down to 1% Should probably be zero Overall level is high for this time of year, but the rains relent, and they've reduced the outflow. The key factor is they reduced the outflow, which conveys confidence IMO They are back in control of the water level

Per a colleague of mine, the Gorges dam has been more full than this several times. From a certain research group: "Three Gorges Dam. “Whatever it takes” is no exaggeration regarding what Beijing has been doing and will do to protect the Three Gorges Dam, the world’s largest hydro power project. The result -- regions both upstream and downstream suffer more, in particular the downstream, but in exchange for reducing the worst case chances. We expect it to stay safe. There has never been, worldwide, a collapse this big in history. "

The Chinese government will sacrifice down stream territory as it has already demonstrated. Dam failure would be shameful in the eyes of the world. Only catastrophic rainfall exceeding the ability to release water could cause a failure.
Not going to happen short of the hand of God getting involved.
It appears that it is being well-managed.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/20/china-three-gorges-dam-highest-level-hydro-electric-floods?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other

40 dam failures world since 2000. The worst failure of a dam in a larger period was in china in 1975, china has 50k réservoirs associés with dams, and the covid is restricting people flow and maintenance tasks. The risk of failure is better than zero by a significant amount. The risk is certainly not zero and I'm beginning to question the verity of gjp when the whole 'game' seems to be to predict whatever the crowd is and then your score is magnified or when I'm seeing people with multiple accounts manipulating the crowd predictions by simply predicting multiple times over several accounts.
Put on your bucket list to visit the Three Gorges Dam and take a cruise on the Yangtze and go thru the locks. It is a humbling experience.
Black Swan
The water receded to 165 meters Monday…but heavy rains through wednesday https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Natural-disasters/Three-Gorges-Dam-waters-drop-from-peak-but-flood-risk-persists
Keeping it the same. Seems like there is lots of flow but hard to see it collapsing
Actually I thought I'd correct for my overly pessimistic view by forecasting zero.

No fault of the Chinese, but I’m reasoning the dam was built to withstand a 1 in 1000 year flood. Which, over a 10 years would mean a 1% chance of failure. Not small odds. Problem for China is, it’s at its limit, and another half meter of rain is predicted to fall in the catchment over the next ten days. It will take time to arrive, but it’s going to be a very close run thing.
Just acknowledging the possibility.
Very rare for dams to fail due to excess water. The dam can always run off water to minimize risk of failure.
Bumping this up to 6% for a short period to account for current conditions. https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Natural-disasters/As-water-crests-Three-Gorges-Dam-crisis-puts-400m-at-risk
https://www.ft.com/content/58ed7f38-507d-4727-887a-e50afa934b92
Going up to 5% in light of recent news before I reevaluate
55%, 64%, 80% over the next three days with the highest probability for failure in the in the week, given the projected weather patterns being sunday the 26th I will revisit throughout the week.
Keeping 0% forecast... of course I'm not really saying it's 0%, but below 0.5%.
High potential for overtopping and subsequent collapse. Punting high to compensate for previous zero & will go back down if weather eases.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-floods-threegorges/water-levels-at-chinas-three-gorges-near-maximum-after-flooding-rains-idUSKBN25H0CJ Going up to 1 on this for a while; probably don't need to.

I think they're almost through with the so called "5th flood wave", as inflow reduced more sharply recently. (On their webcam you can see they're showing a light projection show right now, maybe for the relief being felt...) However, they're not completely out of the weed yet, since rainfall in the very region will add to the stress on the dam and will continue until at least Tuesday 25 August 2020.

Spillway capacity is more than double what is currently being used. Weather is slated to improve over coming weeks. Raised estimated likelihood of failure from 1% to 2% due to China's history is downplaying/mismanaging crises.
The Dam is at near maximum capacity - if it is going to happen, it is going to happen soon.
"An over flowing dam is a worst case scenario because it produces significant damage and can lead to the entire thing collapsing"
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-floods-threegorges-idUSKBN25H0CJ

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/20/china-three-gorges-dam-highest-level-hydro-electric-floods

Going from 8% to 9% Water level is rising extremely fast. Inflows are almost double Outflow, which is at maximum. That means the Dam operators can not control the water level. As I type, the water level is rising above the July Peak. And the typical seasonal peak is still more than 6 weeks away.

I admit this isn’t looking good at all. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/aug/20/china-three-gorges-dam-highest-level-hydro-electric-floods Continue to believe Winnie The Pooh will not allow dam failure. Given persons both within and outside party are voicing concern at his dictatorial bent, he can not afford impact to something viewed to be as prestigious as this and able to handle once in millennium flooding. They will sacrifice other areas to flooding to save the dam. They can hold back 175m of water. Currently 165.5. I predict a little over 170. It’s going to be close. Regardless repairs will be required. As earlier noted one of my friends. (Engineer) noted premature aging of this structure.

"Water levels at China’s Three Gorges dam are at their highest ever as months of torrential rain overwhelm the country’s flood defences ... The upper reaches of the Yangtze river are facing their fifth round of flooding this summer ... The flow rate of water into the massive Three Gorges dam was at 75,000 cubic metres a second on Thursday, topping the previous 2012 record of 71,200, according to Chinese state media." https://www.ft.com/content/58ed7f38-507d-4727-887a-e50afa934b92

The gates should have been opened far earlier to full capacity to lower the water level further between 31 July 2020 and 13 August 2020. There has obviously been a false certainty among the Water Management responsible forecasters. At current speed (roughly +2.5meters per day), water level will have reached absolute maximum capacity within just five days. If the dam has not burst by then, a major leak or spill appears inevitable after 25 August 2020.
Current heavy rains, near capacity. The probability is still low, but just above zero.
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/historic-flooding-presents-biggest-ever-challenge-for-chinas-massive-three-gorges-dam-11597875385

Going from 3% to 8% Max Height is 175, It reaches that level on a regular basis. However, it appears that in July this resulted in some minor deformations. At it's current age, that should not be happening. It appears that despite all flood gates being open, the water level continues to rise. While below Maximum, it's rising fast http://3gd.mooo.com/
http://3gd.mooo.com

Global Times from June: “The dam is designed to meet "once-in-a-millennium" water level at 175 meters or flow up to 70,000 cubic meters per second. Currently, the 147-meter water level and 26,500 cubic meters per second levels are absolutely safe for the dam to bear, Guo told the Global Times on Monday.“ https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1192443.shtml

Winnie the Pooh can’t afford failure. Will flood other areas as required to avoid loss of face. “ Officials have warned that huge volumes of water are building up behind the Three Gorges dam - a massive hydroelectric project on the Yangtze.” https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-53831271
A traditional local saying holds that if the Buddha's feet get wet, Chengdu which has a population of 16 million people will flood too

According to http://3gd.mooo.com/ the water level is rising by approx. 1 meter per day as of 18 August 2020, to 159m compared to a low of 153m on 14 August. In the meantime, outflow has expanded to the highest level on record since 20 July 2020 to almost 45k m³ per sec. Problematically, inflow has expanded even quicker, to currently about 67k m³ per sec, which leaves a surplus of more than 20k m³/s for the dam to hold for the time being, or up to 1.75mn m³ per day.
[ignore]
If it did happen, it would have been a result of human error with the flood controls and not due to the dam's structure failing.

"The average amount of annual precipitation is: 999.9 mm (39.37 in)", typical jun/jul months are the wettest with the month raising concern being about 200mm. The dam operators are saying that the measured flow was 61k m^3/s and that the design threshold is twice that...the dam is 26 years old from conception but not actually fully complete until 2015 so I'd say that makes it reasonably new...not that new things don't fail...it's not a zero chance...but the designer/operators hubris in saying that "nothing could topple the dam in 500 years" is colorful. All of Hubei province is (according to wikipedia) ~186km^2 and the catchment area for the three gorges reservoir looks like something about 1/3 to 2/3 (so 62000-124000 km^2) of the total area of the province. There is about 34.8mm predicted total average rainfall for the next ten days. Which could produce somewhere between 1000 m^3 and 519000 m^3 which is not the measured flow rate at the dam only the area measured precipitation...Then too there was typhoon lekima on 10 Aug and a pos.tropical storm in the next three to four days moving through the SCS. A lot of the histrionics seem to be around 20Jun-19Jul which is a bit out of date...

The monsoon season appears to be over for this region. The Dam survived one of the worst floods in decades an continues to work with out any recent issues. The flood the area seemed to have caused environmental issues, transitional risk, and property damage, which were the most important issues.

InFlow recently has exceeded the outflow, extended forecast calls for more rain in the Yangtze River Valley. But, According to the Los Angeles times On July 19 Chinese government blew up a bridge on the Chuhe River in Anhui province in an attempt to stem further flooding. I believe that this shows the lengths the government will go to To protect the Three Gorges dam.

The "Upstream: Cuntan/Chongqing" figures/charts look like it's getting really serious upstream this time around. And for the next 9-10 days thunderstorm will occur daily in the Wuhan region or upstream, and there's no way the monsoon season will lose steam.
Inflows are still exceeding outflows which are at their max, so the level of the reservoir is rising. I wonder what the forecast is for weather upstream from the dam?

Increasing odds as 4th flood hits the Yangtze river and the waters of the There Gorges Dam are "rapidly rising" (1.8 million cubic feet/sec on aug 14th; the biggest influx this year. It is expected to rise to 2 million) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jor9KK3Xpfc

They're through the worst of the weather, structural integrity would have to be seriously compromised for the condition to be met.
It appears that the worst flooding has passed. However, there may be another unexpected flood.
I think the worst has passed for between now and October 1st

The immediate flood has passed, so a failure at this point would require another massive monsoon and/or that the damage to the dam is much more serious than has been admitted. This seems extremely unlikely but not impossible.
re-affirming. The water level in the reservoir continues to fall as inflows have decreased. Releases have stayed high, but not at the max.

The worst seems to be over, but water levels are still high. The dam is said to have been 'deformed slightly' but a breach appears very unlikely now. This article is almost three weeks old, and seems to mark the point of highest risk. https://asiatimes.com/2020/07/three-gorges-dam-deformed-but-safe-say-operators/
Low probability. China's leadership knows that the world is watching them and they will do everything in their power to prevent failure. It's a question of their standing in the world.
Incremental update.
Yes, but the news about it will not leak out until after 1 October 2020
The conspiracy theory behind this is weird but oh well. Seems improbable, I've found articles like this about the dam going back to 2003 so it seems unlikely from the offset.

Currently the Dam if accounts are to be believed is quiet stressed. If the 10 day regional forecast is to be believed this will be the 4th significant flood the Dam has faced this year and officials claim there are significant vibrations from the currently open 7 sluice gates

We have now passed the peak of the rainy season with no indication that the Dam was ever or is about to fail due to precipitation. It is still possible that some cataclysmic event (earthquake) could disrupt or destroy it, but in the two months remaining, that is an incredibly remote possibility.
It was built before things got really cheap in China.
Going down 1% to 3
Interesting article. https://www.cnn.com/style/article/china-three-gorges-dam-intl-hnk-dst/index.html We are probably through the worst of the rainy season so no but next year?
The effects of the next wave of upstream water are having little effect [1]. Downgrading again
Dont think it will, but the location is in a frequent earthquake zone. So only time will tell.
The Chinese government would sacrifice more land and upriver towns before letting the Dam fail. The probability will go down as it is unlikely that rainfall keeps at this level.

I’ve shared this link before, and recommend others follow him on Twitter for the duration of this forecast - he has provided reliably accurate updates on the TGD. One of the questions I had was what happened to all the water upstream, such as in Cuntan. He provides a plausible explanation here [1], which is why I’m increasing my probability by 1%. I’ll follow inflow, water levels, and outflow at the TGD closely over the next 24-72 to see if there’s cause to increase further, or decrease again.

Seems unlikely, a large project like this will have been designed to the extreme, and I would expect they would allow a controlled release of large volumes of water before any large threat to the dam itself occurred.

It was brought to my attention that the Chinese Approach to flood control is the opposite of the Corp Of Engineers in the United States. Here we hold the water to prevent a flood, in a flood pool behind a dam. There the philosophy is to speed the water downstream, dams are collectors for a drainage system. Ergo the dam has different set of engineering requirements. So the durability under record prolonged flood pools is unknown.
Flooding should be included in the stability of the dam

Even after two large inflow peaks, the dam remains below max level (175m), but the rainy season still has at least a month to go and could extend through September if the unusual conditions this summer persist. The monitoring info (http://3gd.mooo.com, thx @Anneinak!) does suggest that the dam engineers are controlling the level well but it also shows the limits to what they can do, the outflow stays in the 40-45K m3/s range throughout. Still seems unlikely that a dam designed (partially) for flood control would fail under conditions that seem to be within its operating tolerances (need more research on this...).
inflow has reduced significantly. Outflow have been reduced some too because reservoir level has dropped several feet.

First off, I have to self-report a bias against China. The fact that this has come to light, despite the interests of the Chinese government to keep it under wraps, is a sign that the concerns are warranted, and probably more serious than reported. Of course, people have been saying that the dam will break since 2018, and it hasn't happened. Though recently, sections of the dam have already moved under the growing water pressure, water is being released as a precaution and over 30 million Chinese have been evacuated. The weather forecast for Zigui County forecasts rain to continue incessantly in the next 10 days. The government has already blasted open a dam in Anhui. Chinese Dams have been poorly maintained and rarely reinforced. Furthermore, the Dam is more vanity project than hydro-electic engineering marvel (Mao Zedong was obsessed with the dam); in spite of its enormous size, it fails to produce as much electricity as the Itaipu Dam - a dam with 2/3rd its capacity and turbines. The US Glen Canyon Dam also failed in response to the floods of 1983. Also noteworthy: just days after the first filling of the reservoir of the Three Gorges Dam, around 80 hairline cracks were observed in the dam's structure. Since then, Chinese inspection has stated that "163,000 concrete units were assessed (...) with a pass rate of 100%". However, the dam has not been inspected by Dutch dam experts, despite Sino-Dutch infrastructural cooperation.

State intervention will occur in time due to the financial impact a dam fail will entail. Chinese CCP will not want to be seen to work with other states to resolve this but back-channel mechanisms for getting funding in place while allowing the perception of Chinese state acting alone will occur. This would have a gobally significant impact and all steps will be taken to ensure the dam does not fail.
China would dump water and flood downstream before having a public disaster.
It looks like the operators of the dam are managing things well. In-flow has declined. Out-flow has been steady & high. Water level is lowering.

The consensus of what appear to be fairly expert opinions seems to be “little to no chance” during this window of time. Hat tip to @Anneinak for suggesting another user sort rationales by “most upvoted”.
I am downgrading this to a 0% probability because the current inflow (37k m3/s) is less than the current discharge (40k m3/s).[1]

The odds of any dam failing in a year are 1 in 10,000, so to happen in two months is around 0.00167%. Dams have life expectancies of around 50 years, as well, but the Three Gorges Dam is only 14 years old, so it is expected to continue for several decades more. However, this year China has seen record-breaking levels of rainfall and monsoon season lasts until the end of September, so it's failure is not completely out of the question.
There are significant rain storms in the area. The dam is only a few feet from capacity.
Initial forecast. Crowd forecast at 4%. Basing this on current weather and other commenters.

Spillway capacity is supposedly 116,000 m^3 / sec (4.1 million CFS), almost double incoming floodwaters. I suspect China would draw down impounded water and cause downstream flooding if dam failure seemed imminent.

Taking into account the definition of failure in the question might very well include that the water level exceeds the height of the dam, this begins to look like a likely possibility, particularly after reading the comments from @Anneinak
https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3974752

Unlikely but possible. One of my friends (engineer) who has looked at it says it hasn’t been maintained as well as it could be. Unlikely in this timeframe. They will sacrifice other locations first before risking dam.
reference this site: http://3gd.mooo.com You can see a peak and then drop in inflow, slight uptick in discharge rate, and the current level is LESS than when the inflow was last as high (July 18/19)

All factors that can contribute to the dam's failiure are measurable (Rainfall, structural integrity etc). One would expect the chinese govement, after having followed standard operating procedures to mitigate against failiure (Opening of flood gates) , to act in an extraordinary fashion if faced with a serious risk of failiure: Something we have not yet seen.

Still a long shot, but due to continued flooding, an uncontrolled release looks more likely by the day. Chinese state media are far from quiet of the potentially catastrophic risks. What is contentious is what kind of releases will be deemed uncontrolled - as I am not anticipating the dam breaking (which is <1%) http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-07/27/c_139244272_2.htm https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Natural-disasters/China-warns-of-new-floods-as-Three-Gorges-Dam-under-pressure

The dam can handle up to 83.7 million liters/second and it's currently operated around 60. That's obviously not great, but it's within parameters. However, this is the THIRD flood this monsoon season already, so I'll check back as the weather shows us what she's going to do.
I might be overreacting, but checking the news and the opinion of other really good forecasters here, I will increase the probability a bit for the time being.

The Cuntan Dam, which is upstream from the TGD, is leveling off and starting to possibly drop. Meanwhile the discharge rate at the TGD remains well below threshold. The water level is rising, and I’m going to keep an eye on that, but we’re still ~20m below max height. Supposedly there will be more rain upstream later this week, but that will take time to make its way down to the TGD.

I spoke with a retired consulting engineer who worked on the project and sent him the picture of the warped dam from the Taiwan news agency. He said if it was actually like that, it would have already failed. He thought the whole thing was nonsense.
Third flood now https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3974752
https://www.theepochtimes.com/chinas-third-peak-of-flooding-this-year-hits-yangtze-river_3438778.html
Currently, based on reported inflow, water level, and discharge, that the dam is operating just inside optimal parameters.
High water out of season means less capacity when normal rains arrive. It may come down to the training of the staff managing the flood gates.

Water level at the Dam Seasonally rising from around the 145 meter level in late summer and peaks in October / November time frame around the 170 to 175 level The current high water level is not the issue and seeing the water level rise to 170 to 175 meters shouldn't be a problem. The problem is it reached 164 meters in July, now back down to about 158 meters. It should be 10 meters lower than it currently is, and all the water that will fill it to capacity is still yet to come. It's less than 20 years old. Failure shouldn't be expected for many years. It should be effectively <0.05%, so call it zero. I'm at 4% because of the currently high water level BEFORE the seasonal rise is expected
useful link to observe the water level in Three Gorges Reservoir. 185 metres is the dam collapse threshold. http://3gd.mooo.com/
To necessary to fail in this short time frame. All the money will be thrown at it to make sure it doesn't fail. It may do in time, but not in this time frame.
95% of a 0%, 10% of a 10%? Some knightian uncertainty given that I don't know much about the topic. Will update as time goes on.

The Three Gorges Dam is very unlikely to fail in the near future. Any failure would be catastrophic and China's government will do all that they can to control the rising water levels by opening floodgates, etc.

The Three Gorges Dam held during the recent record high flood level, so it would stand to reason that if it held then, it won't fail anytime soon. The Chinese have been building magnificent structures for thousands of years, with some lasting for centuries. I think these engineers deserve some credit and faith in their design.

China’s construction and infrastructure capacity and the ability to direct resources without political infighting, plus access to labor and capital make it likely that any issues would be addressed rapidly
Rain fall versus construction and Yangtze take-off
The Chinese are proving to be really good at putting up walls and containing things lately.

"Two months of rains have swelled the Yangtze and the Three Gorges Dam can handle 84 million litres of water per second. In recent days, the water inflow reached 61 million litres per second. Heavy rainfall is expected to pound the Yangtze again with floods expected." https://www.wionews.com/world/chinas-flood-crisis-deepens-as-several-dams-may-collapse-315235
I feel it is unlikely to happen. The Dam is designed to withstand the rains, earthquakes etc and a failure in the near term is unlikely.
Back up, now that the crowd is shifting.

News this week confirmed that the Three Gorges Dam buckled on the 18th when flooding caused water levels to surge 18.59 meters in 48 hours (https://asiatimes.com/2020/07/yangtze-deluge-tests-limits-of-three-gorges-dam/). This brought the water level to 162 meters. The Dam Collapse threshold is 185 (or maybe 181?) meters. Meanwhile, several dams upstream have collapsed while record rainfall continues.
Gates will probably continue to be opened affecting those downstream rather than risk the fallout of it actually failing.
I think it is highly unlikely this dam falls apart any time soon.

As far as I know, the materials and the calculation of the dam was made using hight safety parameters and the best equipment (ej: transformers where buy in Germany). So there is very low probability of failure.

The dam is already controversial, so any story on it will be far reaching and potentially exaggerated. The Chinese have admitted to some movement to the dam but say it's within normal parameters. Reading this question carefully reveals there are actually two independent events that need to be considered 1.) Structural failure of the dam and 2.) An overflow or overtopping of the dam (meets the criteria of "uncontrolled release"). The dam is a relatively new reinforced concrete gravity dam. The main body was completed in 2006. The probability of that type of dam built as recently as 2006 failing in the question timeframe is negligible. Not putting weight in reports of cracking. All concrete cracks. What matters is the ingress of water into the cracks and the initiation of corrosion of the steel reinforment. This happens but takes time. The question is really what is the return period (recurrence interval) of the flood event that would cause an overtopping/overflowing of the dam...adjusted for the remaining question timeframe and current flooding levels

The average dam has a .01% chance of failing in a given year. A concrete dam like Three Gorges fails about 8x less frequently. There are about 95 days between now and Oct 1, or 26% of a year. .01/8x.26 is zero for this exercise.
The global dam failure rate is 1:10000 per year, or .0001%. I will adjust this base rate given more information specific to the Three Gorges Dam.

There does not appear to be a definition of the term ‘Dam Fail’ and an associated quantification of degree of structural damage. Such an event is described as an uncontrolled release of water due to structural or deficient issues with the dam and range from minor to catastrophic. The National Interagency Committee on Dam Safety rates dams as high hazard dams(potential loss of life); Significant dams (no loss of life, but severe economic, environmental or serious damage; Low hazard dams causing limited damage to property. The 3 Gorges Dam is obviously an extremely high Hazard dam. However, the question concerns a dam fail and not the extent of damage and so a 'fail' could be something minor. The 3 gorges dam has 23 spillways and 22 surface sluice gates to release flood water that can apparently handle the flood waters.

This is a gravity concrete dam, which means it relies on its own weight for stability. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Gorges_Dam

There were 3,523 incidents of dam failure from 1954 to 2013 (He et al. 2008; Zhao 2014) that caused significant loss of life and economic losses in china. This averages out to 67 dam failures, of various sizes per year. There are approx 87,000 dams in total. Given this, the three gorges dam broadly speaking has .08 chance of failing this year. There is significant flooding atm, which could increase probability of failure, but the concrete dam wall is 181 m (594 ft) high above the rock basis and has a max capacity water level of 175 m (wiki) Water level currently seems to be at 145-7 m from the articles I can find, which is well within capacity. The dam has passed quality checks, is a relatively new project (old dams fail more often) and there's a large amount of research done on seismic activity in the area. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674984715300756 https://journal.probeinternational.org/2014/04/07/three-gorges-dam-triggers-frequent-seismic-activities/ https://www.slu.edu/news/2018/september/earthquake-research.php There are rumors of buckling and deformation and a google earth image going around (https://www.foxnews.com/world/integrity-of-chinas-three-gorges-dam-questioned-despite-china-officials-dismissing-it-as-safe) but I looked myself, and google earth currently shows shows no buckling, nor could I find any inconsistencies, so Ima say probs not, image seems fake.
